conclusion: To find the maximum value of the electromotive force (EMF) generated by the alternating current generator, we need to use the principles of electromagnetic induction.
The EMF generated in a coil rotating in a magnetic field is given by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = -N \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \).
\( \mathcal{E} \) is the induced EMF, \( N \) is the number of turns in the coil, \( \Phi \) is the magnetic flux through the coil, \( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} \) is the rate of change of the magnetic flux.
Given that the magnetic flux \( \Phi \) varies sinusoidally with time, we can express it as: \( \Phi(t) = \Phi_0 \sin(\omega t) \).
\( \Phi_0 \) is the maximum magnetic flux, \( \omega \) is the angular frequency of the rotation.
The rate of change of the magnetic flux is: \( \frac{d\Phi}{dt} = \Phi_0 \omega \cos(\omega t) \).
The maximum value of the EMF occurs when \( \cos(\omega t) = 1 \), so \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = N \Phi_0 \omega \).
From the graph in Figure (Z), we can determine the maximum magnetic flux \( \Phi_0 \) and the period \( T \) of the sinusoidal variation.
The period \( T \) is the time it takes for one complete cycle, and the angular frequency \( \omega \) is related to the period by: \( \omega = \frac{2\pi}{T} \).
Given: \( N = 100 \) (number of turns), \( \Phi_0 = 2.0 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{Wb} \) (maximum magnetic flux), \( T = 6.28 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{s} \) (period from the graph).
The maximum value of the electromotive force generated by the alternating current generator is \( 200 \, \text{V} \).
